Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Development of Multiphoton Photoacoustic Microscopy for High-Resolution Imaging

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1055359
Applegate

This proposal addresses the development of multiphoton photoacoustic microscopy via resonant and non-resonant two-photon absorption. The weak attenuation of acoustic emission in tissue holds the promise of improving the maximum imaging depth of nonlinear microscopy by a factor of 4. An imaging depth of ~2 mm would allow subcellular imaging completely through nearly all areas of the human epithelium where the majority of cancer begins. 2 mm also reaches a significant portion of the mouse anatomy which is used extensively in drug testing and as the model for numerous human diseases. Absorption based nonlinear microscopy increases the pool of potential target molecular species. Essentially all biomolecules are capable of absorbing light. If they exist in high enough concentrations they could be imaged with the developed technology. Using endogenous molecular contrast simplifies the application of nonlinear microscopy to higher organisms including humans because it obviates the need for the delivery of molecular probes to the target molecule or morphology. These techniques potentially open up new avenues of research by enabling the high-resolution 3-D visualization of concentrations/dynamics of biomolecular species (e.g. hemoglobin and cytochrome c) which are essentially invisible to nonlinear microscopy at imaging depths several times deeper than the current state of the art. The imaging techniques do not require exogenous molecular tags for molecular contrast so they are readily applicable to higher organisms including humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary scientific goal of this reasearch was to improve the resolution of photoacoustic microscopy. Photoacoustic microscopy is an emerging imaging technology that is finding applications in biology as well as medical imaging. Our efforts have improved the resolution approximately a factor of 10 to enable subcellular resolution in all 3 dimensions. Our approach has been further refined to require only a very simple modification of a standard photoacoustic microscope. Recent development has lead to the combination with reflectance confocal microscopy and the ability to do multispectral imaging to measure transient absorption spectra at every pixel. High resolution photoacoustic microscopy can provide insights into the local biochemsitry within individual cells. This technology can be used to support research into a wide variety of human diseases that begin at the cellular/subcellular level, e.g. cancer.

Recent advances have made it possible to directly image cytochromes in cells (fibroblasts) and potentially determine the oxidized to reduced ratio. Cytrochromes are important for electron transport in biological systems, e.g. metabolism. The oxidized to reduced ratio can provide insights into the status of the imaged cell. For instance, cancer cells typically exhibit higher metabolic activity which will shift this ratio. The attached image shows the reflectance confocal image and photoacoustic image of a fixed fibroblast undergoing cell death. The photoacoustic image signal is likely due to cytochrome c. 

Three students were trained as part of this research. The first to graduate is currently the CEO of a health-care related start-up company. The second just started as an Assistant Professor at the University of Central Oklahomoa. The third is a research scientiest at Texas A&M University.

This grant also supported the development of a teaching module for teaching undergraduate and graduate students about photoacoustic imaging.
